The other dish Penne Arribiata the penne seemed a few days old a re-heated.. no flavor.. Arrabiata means "hot temper" or something to that effect... yet this had no heat or flavor! NASTY!!

Avoid this place..
author: Nana W.

description: Complete tourist trap. Two words to describe it "Olive Garden"
author: Avinash S.

description:
This is what I wanted--good, simple food, a nice glass of wine, and to relax and enjoy my meal. L'Ottavo hit all the marks. I had a spinach salad with sun-dried tomatoes, linguine pescatore, and a glass of pinot grigio.

Sounds simple, but it's amazing how often restaurants get it wrong. The linguine pescatore was served with a generous helping of mussels, clams, prawns, and salmon in a white wine marinara sauce. Both the seafood and the pasta were cooked perfectly, and weren't overpowered by garlic, as seems to be the trend these days.

The spinach salad was also good. I could have easily ordered it and an appetizer and been full.

My total meal was $38 before tip. The food was worth it, and the service was good. I would definitely go back.
author: Jamie S.

description: Nice family friendly restaurant with delicious Italian food paired with friendly service.  We will definitely make this one of our regular stops and recommend it to friends.
author: Margeaux C.

description: Super fancy little Italian joint that you'd miss if you didn't pay strong attention. Very good, mostly tourists, so a little pricier than necessary.
author: Monika M.

description: Quiet intimate setting. It was nice we didn't have to wait to get seated on a Saturday night. The pasta special (Penne with Spicy Italian sausage, broccoli, and sun-dried tomatoes) was definitely a good choice. I also really enjoyed the spinach salad (yummm. candied walnuts!).
author: Debbie C.

description:
This place is fine. I won't exaggerate how good or bad it is. Ultimately, it's a 3.5, and there's no need for me to change that just to claim a poetic license. I give it two shrugs up.

The restauraunt had the  best Caesar salad that I've had in a while. The salad included tomatoes, olives and artichoke hearts, with a Caesar dressing and parmesan, which is the best of all worlds. 

I enjoy the decor. 

I enjoy that service is good, as it tends not to be that busy, so we get a lot of attention. 

I enjoy the fact that it's not very well-known, so there's no overinflated reviews, or unnecessary long lines. It's a great neighborhood spot, that can feel like home, if you treat it with respect.

I enjoy the wine list, and the pink sauce that is both alfredo and marinara (I'm a Gemini).

But the food is just fine. Nothing to write home about, but not bad at all. Not too greasy or overspiced. Not unique.

It's just a restaurant. And I'm not mad at it for that.
author: Kay H.

description:
L'ottavo bravely took our reservation for 17 ppl on a sat nite (note: the occupant capacity of the restaurant is 42 - a nook-sized place). we arrived late, took a while to put in our orders, & still, i don't think they hated us for it. 

the food: amazing!  moderately priced, moderate portions. i had the penne alla marchigiana & it was so yummy (i heart broccoli), i practically inhaled it.  everyone else was super impressed with their dishes, esp those w/the pesto gnocchi - something i must try next time.  i swear they have a magical way of marinating & seasoning every dish (without making yourself feeling grossly obese afterwards).  & dessert!  the chocolate ice cream cheesecake was so perfect, not at all too sweet or heavy as it sounds. 

only minuses was the sand my friend found in her oysters & the lack of parking, but then it is sf.
author: mel c.

description:
Pretty darn good..... I went there for my sister's birthday, and we took up the whole restaurant.  Well, there were 12 of us.  I had the crab bisque, very yummy, and enough creamy goodness, i could have had another bowl, and I had the mare et terre salad, which was also very yummy, but if it only had a few more scallops, I would have been in heaven.  The tiramisu was to die for.
The restaurant itself was very dim, and had a great home-y feeling about it.  And our waitress was great dealing with a whole bunch of people at once. 
I would love to go there again, just maybe with a few close friends, or even just me and my partner. 
Definately recommed it to anyone who wants great Italian food without selling your first-born son.
author: Janet R.

description:
This place straddles the fine line between romantic slash intimate and depressing. That seems like a huge difference, you say! No... no, it isn't. Not at L'Ottavo. There's garlic hanging from the ceiling, dim lighting that is suspiciously fluorescent, austerely rustic decor, and (usually) few diners. It's half creepy, half authentic. I still can't decide. 

I do recommend it for groups of three and up... It seems like a restaurant where you have to bring the party, and they'll just serve the scrumptiousness. I don't think I would come here on a date or with just one other person, unless you're hoping to bore them right into their spaghetti -- although it certainly gives the opposite impression from the outside.

To be honest, it's been a while, so I don't remember what the service was like: I am a huge customer service freak, though, and I don't particularly recall feeling disgruntled after my visit, so I assume it wasn't too bad. I do, however, fondly remember the satiated feeling with which I walked out! I believe some of the favorites amongst my party were the Linguine Carbonara, Insalata Capricciosa, Fettuccine con Gambari, and the home-made tiramisu for dessert.

If you live in the area, I suggest you give this place a shot -- it has enough potential to pleasantly surprise you. If you're just passing by the neighborhood or are a tourist, however, I think there are plenty of safer bets to be made elsewhere in the area.
author: G. J.

description:
The spaghetti bolognese was uninspired.  Sure, I finished it--I'm not saying it was inedible--but it wasn't that good, in spite of the fact that I was hungry at the time.  It took 25 minutes to prepare, which was disappointing.

The service was crisp, and the bread was fresh.

I doubt I'll eat there again.
author: Brian C.

description: We live a couple doors down which makes this place convenient, but regardless, the food is good.  And I think the atmosphere is cute.  I can totally imagine a place like this somewhere in the Italian countryside.  Another Italian restaurant Fino which is a block over gets so much more business, yet the food isn't as good as L'Ottavo!
author: catherine g.

description: I Blame Bloomspot - When I got the half price offer from them to try this place out ($40 deal for 2 entrees, shared app and dessert - worth $80) I looked it up, saw reasonable reviews and bought the voucher. Well, we used it Saturday night and in a few words: Place was pretty empty for a Saturday night - bad sign. Then when I saw them carrying a big bag of bagged lettuce to the front - where someone was prepping salads I knew we had a problem....The good news - they grill seafood okay. No seasoning but seemingly fresh and grilled fine. The salad was heavily overdressed ($12-14), the bread on the table - pedestrian, and the entrees - bland at best - old school grilled steak with too much mushroom sauce - the quality of the steak was so-so (for $30+ dollars) and the Grilled seafood (also close to $30) - pretty plain with boring sauteed veggies on both plates - identical ! We avoided carbs so not sure what the pasta tastes like. Dessert (so much for those carbs) was tiramasu ($8) - and it was actually the highlight of the meal. No one asked if we wanted coffeee and I took that to mean - pass on it. All and all - hardly worth the $40 we paid (plus 18% tip enforced through Bloomspot purchase). We won't return and I suggest that you seriously consider avoiding this joint as well. Plenty of better places in the city. I suspect they are counting on tourists - who eat there once and never return. Meh is being kind - not sure what restaurant these other reviewers ate at but our meal was at best 2 stars (dim ones at that)!!
author: alan c.

description: went here on a busy Thursday night! was looking for Italian food without traveling to North Beach.  Walk up the street from my hotel to this tiny and adorable Italian resturant in SF. The place is intimate and warm.  It had a little "Old Italy"that I hope is authentic.  I'm glad I found this place.  Sauce was great, fish was perfectly done! Something for everyone
author: Kara R.

description: Delicious!! The sauces are extraordinary. The fish was perfectly done, I am told).  For vegetarians your choices are many ... and WOW!
author: David B.

description: Food was so so decent Italian but nothing to write home about antipast was not as exciting as the yelp review suggested or the "homemade" tiramisu, which did not have a nice taste. Service was good but if you are in the San Fran area head to north beach for some Italian
author: C J.

description:
I wasn't too impressed with this place at all.  I stopped in with my Fiancee and future Mother in Law on her visit.  I don't think any of us were especially hungry, it was more of a formality, last meal to see her off, we all pretty much went with soups and salads.

The soups were good from what I gathered, the salads were mediocre, the killer was the shoddy portions and exorbitant prices for what you get.  I was in a seafood mood, and since I wasn't paying, I couldn't bring myself to order anything off the menu other than a salad with prices all at a minimum of $22 an entree.  The Seafood salad sounded fancy enough on the menu, but what I got was barely appetizing, and almost had to force it down, the shrimp was obviously of the frozen variety, rubbery and tasteless, dressing was unmemorable.

I couldn't recommend it unless you wanted to pay too much for lesser quality, I hope there are better options for Italian than this in San Francisco.  I've had better chain food for less than half the price.
author: Tyler D.

description:
I remember going here years ago, and couldn't remember if I enjoyed it or hated it and since I was going to an art event that night right down the street we decided this would be a good place to grab a bit before getting our drink on.

Once I walked inside I remembered the place visually however I still had no recollection of the food or the service so it was almost like dining at a new place or maybe like that movie 50 first dates.

We were seated right away at 8pm on a Saturday night so that was one thing that I will remember for the future. The service was decent, our waiter was a bit flighty but nice and seemed to be somewhat on top of things. The food was A-OK, nothing to complain about, nothing to rave about, that is why I am giving it an A-OK. Will I be back you ask? I would say probably not unless I need a place in the area that I know I can get into quickly and have a decent meal. San Francisco has way to many good restaurants to go back to the average places, I personally rather try a new place I know nothing about. If you are a creature of habit and you want to know you can get a decent meal for a decent price and probably walk right in, then this could very well be your place.
author: Bobby B.

description:
Pretty good food.  The ambiance would make for a great place to sip wine after a great meal with a date.  

Wine selection is limited but they do have a decent selection in what they do have.  They also have some great appetizers.
author: Soh Jai R.

description:
Was in SF for a conference and asked the concierge.  We were pleasantly surprised.  I had the red snapper special.  The fish was cooked just right and the sauce was not overpowering at all.  Accompanied with a couple of fired potatoes and some vegetables, it was a delightful light meal.  Even the house cabernet was tasty.
Go & try this one.
author: Grant P.

description:
L'Ottavo has been a regular stop on the my dining out circuit for some time now. When I first started going I always brought wine and paid for the corkage fee. Their wine list isn't that bad, but if you have particular taste--then bring your own.

This is a great place to bring a date. The lights are low, tables are spaced well, the prices are reasonable and the service just right.

I almost always order off their specials menu. Which, seems to feature the same specials every time. Start off with the Crab Bisque. It's creamy and actually has good amount of shredded crab. If you're picky about presentation, close your eyes and have a friend spoonfeed you.

Now move on to the Capresse salad. It's a simple salad that is difficult, but not impossible, to screw up. L'Ottavo makes a fine one. Good sized, properly proportioned serving. You'll have to request anchovies, which i believe are crucial, otherwise their left off.

For the entree, I usually order the Red Snapper special. Served in a well balanced white wine lemon butter sauce, side of roasted veggies and yummy mashed potatoes. It's pretty damn good.

Now, order the profiteroles, a cup of coffee, pay your bill, tip well the service worth it and walk home with a smile on your face.
author: Timothy F.

description:
Great, homey Italian restaurant. Hearty portions and attentive service. Their coursing was perfect, with salads arriving only after appetizers were finished and a nice break prior to the main course -- which was delicious.

Don't miss the bruschetta. Don't miss the Spinach Salad. And enjoy!!
author: Josie Z.

description:
Small, cozy Italian restaurant on Sutter.  Ambiance was great: very intimate.  We went on a Monday night and the place was practically empty.  Surprising since the food was quite good.  The fusilli was excellent, and I highly recommend the bruschetta for an appetizer.

Our server was lively and picked a good wine for us, though it was somewhat pricey.  The wine list is a bit anemic, and the food prices seemed somewhat high.

Good for a romantic evening, probably not so good for a very large party.

I would recommend this restaurant and most likely return.
author: Rajiv B.

description:
The food is a step above average.  I wasn't feeling too adventurous, so I tried pretty safe menu items -- caprese salad and the fettucine bolognese.  I also picked on my friends' dishes-- crab bisque, minestrone, and pasta dishes.  The portions are fair and the prices are moderate.  They have a decent wine list.

What I like most about this restaurant is that its cozy and intimate.  There's  plenty of space between tables and its dimly lit.   (Everyone looks good in dim lighting.)  I could see how this may be a good place for a date.  Our server was attentive.

Try it if you happen to be passing through the neighborhood, but don't go out of your way to get here.
author: W D.

description:
Great service, cute and cozy ambiance, delish food.  Pasta carbonara is an absolute indulgence when you want something creamy, perfect al dente pasta, with fresh peas and lots of pancetta.  Minus one star because the desserts are unimpressive, and it's a bit on the high end of the price range for the neighborhood Italian restaurant.  

However, it's better than other similar restaurants in the area, such as Zingari's, Colombini's or Bella Venezia.
author: Maple L.

description:
Went on 12/15 for a friend's birthday. Had a lot of people there and service was pretty good for the number. I was a late arrival and it took a long time for the waiter to come by to even get a drink order. I ordered the chianti which was good. For dinner I ordered the fish fettucini, don't remember the name of the dish. Others also ordered the same dish, including one woman who ordered before me and the forgot to put hers (or mine) in. I think it was hers, as I am incredibly special and they would never forget mine. Another 30 minutes before she saw her meal. The salmon was great, the shrimp was overcooked, the mussels and clams were good. Prices were reasonable for food, coffee was over the top--something like $4 for a cup.
Probably won't go again.
author: Lisa P.

description: The food was great and the staff was nice.  The atmosphere was OK.  We were going to the show and it was just two blocks to the theater.  We told them we needed to hurry, and they took good care of us.
author: Kirk D.

description:
You must experience this restaurant.

First of all, they were accommodating enough to serve a group of ten, when it is a smaller restaurant.  You gotta love restaurants that really take care to please the customers.  Especially with waiters like Marco - he was composed and friendly, but not in your face.  Service was speedy and he even spoke some Italian with us!  He was also gracious enough to bring out some tiramisu for my friend's birthday!

The food was delicious.  There is something for everyone.  The canelone was PHENOMENAL.  A few of us have traveled and studied abroad in Italy and we all thought this food was very authentic tasting.  Great bottle of house red!

Perfect for a date, great for a group of friends!  Great music and ambiance, overall a memorable and wonderful experience.  We will be back.  Look for me again Marco!
author: Jenni B.

description: Good find for eating in San Francisco.  Not far from Union Square - worth the hike up Sutter.  Homemade pasta was a pleasant surprise.  I had the mussels and clams with linguine with a very nice tomato sauce.  Very well prepared and a good value for a "downtown" spot.  I also like the assortment of Italian beers.  Service was "relaxed."  Don't expect to get in and right out - but it was fine for us.  I didn't give it a fourth star mainly because it was a neighborhood spot and not really "fine" dining.  I would go back.
author: Ted E.

description: I came here on my 30th birthday with a party of 20 (I think.  I got pretty drunk, but there were a lot us).  They were very accommodating and set up a big table for all of us.  The food was good, affordable and everyone liked it.
author: Mike A.

description: Meal was delicious. i had the fuccili gorgonzola. It was filling in the most spectacular way. All compliments from the rest the our group. You get great bread once you order, too, which I feel is a rare treat these days. Worth a try. I'd definitely come back.
author: James R.

description:
I came to this restaurant for the first time after having met the owner (Marco) on Golden Gate Transit one night on my way home when I was living in Marin. We struck up a conversation, in which he talked about his daughters and mentioned to me that he owned a restaurant near Union Square. After a few bus conversations, he gave me his card and I promptly made reservations, not really knowing what to expect since I had never even heard of this place before.

Contrary to what appears to be the Yelp! opinion, I have always found the portions to be more than sufficient, as I can never finish my food. The service is amazing, even when I am served by someone other than Marco, I always get dessert or a Grolsch (sometimes both) on the house, and leave feeling as if I am stepping out of a different country. 

The prices here are really about average for a business-casual restaurant, seeing as I have worked in fine dining in the past, the portions are, again, more than satisfactory, it's within perfect distance of the theater district, and it usually has openings for dinner due to its low profile.

A great choice for a romantic night out!
author: Liz O.

description: Living in Nob Hill we have a lot of choice within walking distance.  Last night (a Tues.) the wife and I went out for a stroll to find a romantic restaurant and came across L'Ottavo's. We found it to be welcoming, have attentive service, good food with a  cozy "old world" feeling.
author: Bryan A.

description: Not a very good value when compared to what you might find at other Italian restaurants, as I have had much better Italian food at the same price, and had similar Italian food elsewhere for nearly half of the price. The decor is a bit dated and lighting is a bit too dim for my liking, but I am sure tourists might appreciate it, otherwise it still feels warm and cozy. It does not get very loud inside, so it is a pretty decent place to have a conversation over a meal, and it might be considered romantic by some. They serve some very nice Chiantis by the glass and the desserts are very good, I would recommend any of the chocolate or mocha tortes with gelato, so yum! As for the appetizers and entrees. Well, the salads are small for the price, but sufficient. The bruschetta might be good for someone who really loves garlic, but a tad heavy on the garlic for my liking. The Pescatorre Linguini was nothing to brag about, sauce was rather bland, and I felt as if I could have made something much better at home in a 15 minutes and for a tiny fraction of the price. The Veal was far from generous, very small slices, and served with some sad little potato home fries and veggies, which really got lost in the the rest of the sauce. Had to wait just over 5 minutes to get two glasses of water and some bread on the table, but otherwise the server was friendly and did her job well.
author: J H.

description: L'Ottavo was pitiful.  I mean hands down the worst experience in a restaurant I have ever had.  Took forever to be greeted at the table, even longer to get our bread and ages to receive what they are trying to pass off as a meal.  The pomodoro sauce was literally chunks of tomato in oil over spaghetti.  Despicable. The chef was wandering around the bar and left drinking the glass of wine in his hand, hard to get any work done when you're drinking on the job.  Save yourself the trouble and  go to any of the other four restaurants a stone's throw away.  Such as Sanraku or Ryoko's  (sushi) Piraat pizzeria (trust me it's better than that dump) or Le Colonial (French-Vietnamese)
author: Ikey S.

description: We randomly wandered in after a show last week, and I feel so lucky it was this place and not the others we briefly considered walking by.  I rarely write reviews, but this place impressed me so much I felt compelled to. The food is excellent! My girlfriend had trout and I had veal, and while I was hoping for a GOOD meal, I was blown away by the bold richness of flavor. I would've expected them to charge more than $40 for entrees of this quality; at ~$20 / dish this food is a steal. By the time we sampled their homemade tiramisu, we were hooked... We will definitely be back soon. Fantastic!
author: David B.

description: This place was very good and better than what I had expected based on some of the reviews.  The server did not appear too happy when we showed up at 9:30 for dinner on a Thursday so I got the impression they were closing soon, but when we left around 10:30 they were still seating people.  It is nice to have a place close to home that will serve food at that hour on a weeknight.  The ravioli and cannelloni were delicious.  The red house wine was also very good.  I will definitely be going back to try more pastas!
author: Rise G.

description: Came here while om business with my uncle, who lives in the area and has eaten here many times and knows the owner - kind of. This has a quaint, real Italian feel to it that is far superior to the Italian chain restaurants. I had veal piccata, which was superb. Veal was very tender and not soaked in butter. Some people might say the portion is small, bit I'd rather have a smaller portion of excellent veal than a larger portion of tough veal. The tiramasu was exceptional and the price of a decent bottle of wine was very reasonable. With all the glitz and crowds around Union Square, step back a street or two and enjoy what SF is known for - family owned and authentic restaurants.
author: David R.

description:
I went to this place tonight based on the relatively good reviews L'Ottavo received on Yelp.  I'm sorry to say that I was rather disappointed.  They could've had an off night...maybe our waiter had just broken up with his girlfriend...I dunno...but I don't think it's worthy of 4 stars.

First, we got there right as the place opened on Saturday evening (5 p.m.).  No, I'm not 80 years old and no, I was not looking for the early bird special...my mom, my sisters and I had just caught a matinee performance of "Jersey Boys" (which I HIGHLY recommend, by the way) and decided to get an early dinner.

They seated us, no problem.  They handed us our menus, no problem.  Then we waited...and waited...until they finally came to take our order 15 minutes later.  We ordered 4 salads and 2 pasta dishes to split.  Plus, I ordered a glass of wine.

We got: 2 salads split 4 ways (which makes for an incredibly small salad) and my wine never showed up.  I had to ask for it again right before our pasta came.

The salad (though minuscule in size) was tasty.  The pasta (I think it was fettuccine with chicken and eggplant) tasted like something I had whipped up on a Wednesday night after a long day at work.  In other words, it was nothing special.

So, by this time, we had eaten a handful of spinach and a handful of pasta and were still feeling rather peckish, so we ordered dessert.  It was a chocolate torte-ice cream-thing and was, by far, the only redeeming aspect of our dinner.

Sorry L'Ottavo...but your sucky service overshadowed your yummy dessert so I have to give you 2 stars.
author: Piper H.

description: Small, dark, removed from the mainsteam L'Ottavo.  Trad'l Italian staff and service.  Romantic with the right person.  Good, reliable, neighborhood joint and not overpriced.  Wine selection okay.
author: A W.

description: I just had my birthday dinner there. They had no problem taking a group on a friday night although it's a small place. We had 10 people and it was great. Everyone enjoyed their dinners- 4 of us had the spinach ravioli, which was super yummy! We had the different types of bruschetta (some were on the specials menu) and also got some good wine. Perfect if you are looking for an intimate setting with affordable prices and quality Italian food.
author: Iguana G.

description: The good news is there is rarely ever a wait to eat here. The bad news is there is a reason why :-) I've eaten here a number of times (usually last minute when there are lines at other Union Square eateries) because honestly, it is not bad. It's a decent place. And I continue to return because it is good - again, not great. Service is OK, but not great by SF standards. The food is OK , but not great by SF standards. Do I sound confused? I guess I am but trust me, the three stars is deserved. If it's a first date or an important dinner meeting go somewhere else. If it's a few casual friends or a family night night out you'll be fine and won't be disappointed.
author: M D.

description: The food was very good but the service sucks. They are too cheap to have enough people working in the restaurant. The young woman serving is charming but she simply can't handle the volume (this was a Sunday night). The guy behind the bar is a surly jerk (ignores customers, never smiles, refused to send the check). I suppose he thinks everyone's a tourist so why bother being nice as they'll never come back. Too bad for him, as we are locals and we were a group of eight - but after the lousy service (and his rudeness) we won't come back. There are plenty of places to have good and authentic Italian food - and places that make you feel welcome. This guy ruins it for me.
author: Jessica V.

description:
very pleasant but nothing special.  the atmosphere is very quaint and slightly old world italian.  we started out with a caprese salad and an eggplant appetizer, both were good.  i had  the putanesca entree which was fine but not as special as one i had recently in the cafeteria at Yahoo!  we shared a pumpkin cheesecake dessert which was also good but not over the top.
the one bit that was very special to me was the coffee.  it was a complete replica of my sicilian grandmother's coffee.  if you're already in the neighborhood and want simple italian food, go here.  not a destination place.
author: Tammy N.

description: Best kind of kept secret! I absolutely love this place. It's my staple Italian in SF.
author: Lily K.

description: Linguini A L'amatriciana and Pasta with broccoli and Anchovies are the best dishes I've had here. Good old traditional style Italian fare. Located close to the theaters on Sutter.
author: Arlene C.

description: My husband and I are staying at the Wyndham Canterbury. This restaurant was recommended as a nearby. We were greeted with buona sera and immediately seated at a perfect table for two. The place was lovely. Lighting perfect. A very clean feel. Service great. Our server was very personable and professional. Our salads were served with gorganzola ( this was not represented on the menu) which would cause my husband horrific problems. When this was brought to her attention she immediately corrected the problem but also asked what other cheese may be a problem.  We had the house white wine which was delightful. I ordered the penne special: sundried tomatoes, broccoli, italian sausage. It was perfect. My husband had the homemade cannelloni with spinach. Again delicious. The soft crusty bread was served with olive oil, balsamic vinegar but the addition of sundried tomatoes plus other seasonings was a treat. We are looking forward to a second visit.
author: Marlene M.

description:
Have to agree with Whitman L. - not the best Italian I've had and certainly not for the price.  The service was pretty good so I don't have a problem there.  We might be a bit spoiled - we often eat at Spalti in Palo Alto (much more authentic and Italian owned/cooked).

If you're really desperate for Italian and everywhere else is closed, it isn't a horrible option, just not our favorite.
author: Kurt K.

description:
went here a long time ago, and it wasn't as bad - but this most recent visit lowers the score big time.

A simple pasta dish - alla amatriciana - and where was my bacon?  You know what its like when you want bacon.  was a very bland, bland pasta dish - all for $18.  wow.

this place lies just inside the tourist zone for union square - crazy 'lil tourists!
author: Tim T.

description: wonderful experience,great waitress,perfect table,fantastic crab chowder,fresh red snapper and the best veal I have had in a long time.........
author: Richard R.

description: exactly what i wanted...i was craving some incredible Italian food and thats what i got...basically if you want a small intimate spot to take your "special" someone" don"t pass it up.
author: Estanisla G.

description: This cheesy, crappy restaurant does not deserve to exist. Had dinner there a few nights ago. We had to wait about 15 minutes before anyone even came to our table to say hello, longer until bread was given. There were only 2 or 3 other couples in the whole restaurant, which was otherwise eerily empty, so it's not like the servers had anything else to do. I asked the waiter for some recommendations, for what's fresh and special, and he was dumbfounded by the question, and flipped it back to me saying I should just order what I want to eat. So, I ordered "home made" linguini with a tomato-anchovy sauce. The tomatoes were from a can, the olives also were old and cheap, and there were no anchovies discernible anywhere on the dish. The pasta didn't taste fresh or home made. The plate was a bunch of dead, worn out ingredients with no flavor or vibrancy whatsoever. The wine list, also, was tired and uninspiring. I did have a crab bisque that was not terrible, but far from noteworthy. And, for this, it was way, way, way overpriced. There is simply no reason for this place to exist and even more, no reason for anyone to waste money and time going to this crap-hole when there are so many special places to try in San Francisco.
author: Eater S.

description:
The description of the two star is pretty much dead on while describing this place... "Meh.  I've experienced better."  It took a while to be greeted and get a table when we walked in, and even longer for someone to actually take our order.  I ordered the bruchetta for a starter, and the spinach salad for dinner (I wasn't really feeling all that hungry).  My husband ordered the special pasta.  Well, when we got our food (finally) he was given his overly greasy pasta with little flavor, and I was given my salad.  Apparently they had forgotten the bruchetta... since I wasn't that hungry anyway, I canceled it.  Well, since they had already made it, they gave it to me for free..... but it was awful.  It was hot (which really takes away from the "fresh" feeling of the bruchetta), was overwhelmed with raw garlic, and was SPICY.  There was nothing to indicate this on the menu, and I can't eat spicy food.  SO glad I didn't have to pay for that.  My salad was good but needed something... perhaps blue cheese or feta, something with a little more flavor.  

All in all, I wouldn't come back unless someone else really wanted to eat there and I was along for the ride.
author: Jo P.

description: Went here for a double date.  Our friend recommended this restaurant and said that he had eaten there 20 times before.  we ordered the smoked salmon for appetizer.  i ordered the linguini, while my girlfriend ordered chicken.  we thoroughly enjoyed our time there.
author: Daniel W.

description: Good but not spectacular.  That about sums it up.  This place is a solid 3.5 but I'm in a decent mood, so I've rounded up.  I came here last weekend for a friend's birthday party and they were very accomodating with our large group of 12.  I ordered the linguine carbonara which was rich and creamy and quite good.  I also shared part of a veal dish with capers and butter sauce.  The veal was pretty forgettable.  All I could taste was the acidity of the capers and not much else.  It could've used a little more salt or butter to balance it out a bit more.  While I didn't partake in the desserts, it seemed most everyone that did was pleased with their offerings.  The service was pretty smooth.   Our waitor was attentive, waters kept full and food arrived promptly and hot.  I don't know if I would ever make a trip out here specifically, but I wouldn't be opposed to coming back here again if I were in the neighborhood.
author: Gary L.

description: Firstly, the second I walked in I thought it would make a great place for a romantic dinner.  Sadly, I was not there on a date, but with a group of 10.  We ended up over here after a couple of tropical drinks at the Fairmont.  We were hungry.  At first we couldn't decide and stood outside the door debating whether we wanted to go in here, or somewhere else, but finally took the plunge.  We had to wait a little bit for our table to be set up, but that's no problem and to be expected.  Our waiter was very nice.  The bread and oil was delicious, and my spinach ravioli very tasty.  I think everyone enjoyed their dishes.  I left before dessert and coffee, but it was the sort of place where you could linger and chat and nobody made you feel rushed.  Prices were pretty reasonable.
author: Susan S.

description: Looks o.k, service is slow but cordial, the food is soso and the 2 house wines we tried were really bad.
author: rj V.

description: We arrived and they were pleasant enough. We ordered our food and it eventually came. Except one dish was wrong. The waiter apologized but insisted that "my dining partner eat without me so it doesn't go cold"...isn't that for me to say?? Needless to say, by the time mine came, his was finished. And my order was still wrong. I didn't bother to say anything though because I just wanted to eat. Until I took my first bite and realized the food was bleh. Wouldn't return. Ever.
author: Danielle S.

description: My husband and I were in the area for a show and we decided to try Fino.  Unfortunately we couldn't get in until 8:30 and the show started at 8.  I usually rely heavily on yelp, but we decided to stroll and just find a place in the neighborhood.  We stumble on L'Ottavo, and we were initially hesitant because at 6:30 on a Sat. there were maybe two people dining.  But we wanted Italian and decided to try it.  We weren't disappointed.  Our waitress was super nice and when we asked for recommendations she told us which dishes had house made pasta and told us what we could swap out if we were interested in other sides.  She seemed reasonable and accomodating.  I wanted about 12 items but settled on the lasagna.  I also had the salad misto.  My husband ordered a chicken special with penne in a cream sauce and the minestrone.  The salad was good and it had a bit of gorgonzola, so it was exactly what I wanted.  We both loved the minestrone.  It was more of a stew than a soup, chock full of perfectly cooked fresh vegetables and a chunk of cheese in the center.  The portion was also huge and really could have been a meal in and of itself.  They also served a fantastic warm bread incredibly crusty on the outside and chewy on the inside.  The dipping sauce was oil, balsamic vinegar, sundried tomatoes, and spices.  As for entrees they were both great but the lasagna was the clear winner.  I have never had better in a restaurant.  Neither of us managed to finish our entrees, so I thought everything was more than adequately portioned, though I guess our chains have got us expecting about three meals worth of italian on one plate.  The prices seemed reasonable for the area, quality of food, and portion size and I think they were slightly cheaper than Fino.  I don't think any entree went above $26, including seafood, veal, and steak.  I didn't see the wine list but my husband ordered a lovely Barbera and the price seemed reasonable for the bottle.  As for the decor, to each his own.  It felt quaint and romantic to me and reminded me of some very cute, authentic restaurants we have gone to in NYC.  By the time we left the place had filled up and there appeared to be a waiting list, so apparently we had just gotten lucky in our timing.
author: Jennifer C.
